column1: # Periodic table used in Horton
# To make the numbers verifiable, the provenance of each data column is given below.
# Only numbers literally mentioned in these papers are included.
# When some data is not provided in the reference for a given element, the cell is left empty.
# A: atomic number
# B: atomic symbol
# C: covalent radius (derived from crystallographic data)
#     B. Cordero, V. Gomez, A. E. Platero-Prats, M. Reves, J. Echeverria, E. Cremades, F. Barragan, and S. Alvarez, Dalton Trans. pp. 2832--2838 (2008)
#     http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/b801115j
#     For carbon the number is a weighted average over the data for different hybridizations.
#     For Mn, Fe, and Co, the number is a weighted average over the data for different spins (high spin and low spin)
# D: Bragg radius (covalent, metallic and ionic bonds, derived from crystallographic data)
#     W. L. Bragg, Phil. Mag. 40, 169 (1920)
# E: Slater radius (covalent, metallic and ionic bonds, derived from crystallographic data)
#     J. C. Slater, J. Chem. Phys. 41, 3199 (1964)
# F: van der Waals radius according to Bondi
#     A. Bondi, J. Phys. Chem. 68, 441 (1964)
# G: van der Waals radii by Truhlar (corrections and additions to Bondi)
#     M. Mantina  A. C. Chamberlin  R. Valero  C. J. Cramer  D. G. Truhlar  J. Phys. Chem. A 113  5806 (2009)
# H: van der Waals radius according to Rowland and Taylor
#     R. S. Rowland and R. Taylor, J. Phys. Chem. 100, 7384 (1996)
# I: van der Waals radii by Batsanov
#     S. S. Batsanov Inorganic Materials 37 871 (2001)
# J: van der Waals radii from the DREIDING FF (R_0 parameter, unit 2angstrom is used so that numbers are divided by 2 upon reading)
#     Stephen L. Mayo, Barry D. Olafson, and William A. Goddard III J. Phys. Chem. 94 8897 (1990)
# K: van der Waals radii from UFF (x_I parameter, unit 2angstrom is used so that numbers are divided by 2 upon reading)
#     A. K. Rappi, C. J. Casewit, K. S. Colwell, W. A. Goddard III, and W. M. Skid J. Am. Chem. Soc. 114 10024 (1992)
# L: van der Waals radii from MM3
#     N. L. Allinger, X. Zhou, and J. Bergsma, Journal of Molecular Structure: THEOCHEM 312, 69 (1994)
# M: Waber-Cromer radius
#     J. T. Waber and D. T. Cromer, J. Chem. Phys. 42, 4116 (1965)
#     For each element, the largest radius of the outer orbitals is taken.
# M: Clementi-Raimondi radius
#     E. Clementi, D. L. Raimondi, W. P. Reinhardt, J. Chem. Phys. 47, 1300 (1967)
number
int
